stem: Following the EHR review, determine the appropriate nursing actions, the most likely condition, and the parameters that require monitoring for the patient.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 10/26 07:00. S: Patient reports a pain level of 7/10 in the lower back, radiating down the left leg. States pain started yesterday after helping a friend move furniture. Denies any previous back issues. O: Patient is alert and oriented x3. Ambulating with a slight limp. Facial grimacing noted with movement. Vitals stable. A: Acute lower back pain, likely musculoskeletal in origin. Rule out nerve impingement. P: Administered ibuprofen 400mg PO. Encouraged to use heat pack. Educated on proper body mechanics and stretching exercises. Will reassess pain level in 1 hour. 10/26 08:00. Patient reports pain level decreased to 5/10 after ibuprofen administration. Continues to use heat pack. Encouraged to continue prescribed regimen.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Alert and oriented, appears uncomfortable. Neuro: Sensation intact in all extremities. Musculoskeletal: Lower back tenderness to palpation, muscle spasm noted. Positive straight leg raise on the left side at 60 degrees. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs. Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Administer Ibuprofen 400mg PO q6h PRN for pain.
  • Apply heat pack to lower back for 20 minutes TID.
  • Encourage ambulation as tolerated.
  • Educate on proper body mechanics.
  • Assess pain level q2h.

actions.text: Assess pain using a standardized pain scale.
Educate on non-pharmacological pain management techniques.
Encourage complete bed rest to prevent further injury.

parameters.text: Skin integrity at the heat pack application site.

rationale.correct: Assessing pain using a standardized scale allows for consistent monitoring and evaluation of the patient's pain experience and the effectiveness of interventions. Educating on non-pharmacological pain management techniques empowers the patient to actively participate in their pain relief and can reduce reliance on medication. Monitoring pain level provides data on the effectiveness of interventions. Skin integrity monitoring prevents burns from the heat pack.
rationale.incorrect: Opioid analgesics are not the first-line treatment for musculoskeletal strain and should be reserved for more severe pain or when other treatments are ineffective. Complete bed rest can weaken muscles and prolong recovery; ambulation as tolerated is preferred. Bowel and bladder function is not typically affected by a musculoskeletal strain unless there is nerve compression. Peripheral pulses are not typically affected by a musculoskeletal strain.

answerBreakdown.text: Assess pain using a standardized pain scale.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Pain scales provide a consistent and objective measure of pain intensity, allowing for effective monitoring and evaluation of treatment effectiveness.
While opioids may be used in some cases, they are not the first-line treatment for musculoskeletal pain due to the risk of side effects and dependence. Other interventions should be tried first.

answerBreakdown.text: Educate on non-pharmacological pain management techniques.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Non-pharmacological techniques such as heat application, stretching, and proper body mechanics can help manage pain and promote healing without the risks associated with medication.

answerBreakdown.text: Encourage complete bed rest to prevent further injury.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Prolonged bed rest can weaken muscles and delay recovery. Encouraging ambulation as tolerated helps maintain muscle strength and promotes circulation.
Monitoring pain level and characteristics is essential to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions and adjust treatment as needed.
Bowel and bladder function are not typically affected by a musculoskeletal strain unless there is nerve compression, which is not indicated in this scenario.

answerBreakdown.text: Skin integrity at the heat pack application site.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Heat application can cause burns if not monitored properly. Assessing skin integrity helps prevent complications.
Peripheral pulses are not typically affected by a musculoskeletal strain. This would be relevant if suspecting vascular compromise, which is not indicated.

clinicalPearls: Musculoskeletal strains are common causes of lower back pain, often resulting from overuse or injury.
Non-pharmacological pain management techniques can be effective in managing musculoskeletal pain and reducing reliance on medication.
Regular assessment and monitoring of pain are essential to evaluate treatment effectiveness and adjust interventions as needed.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing opioid analgesics as a first-line intervention without considering non-pharmacological methods.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize non-pharmacological methods first, and reserve opioid analgesics for more severe pain or when other treatments are ineffective.

mnemonic.title: RICE
mnemonic.expansion: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation (for musculoskeletal injuries)
